paperTitle: Dye-Sensitized Photoelectrosynthesis Cells for Benzyl Alcohol Oxidation Using a Zinc Porphyrin Sensitizer and TEMPO Catalyst

hasContent.text: Synthesis of HOOC-ZnP-TEMPO: HOOC-ZnP-COOH (50 mg, 0.059 mmol, 1.0 equiv) was dissolved in 10 mL of dry DMF and cooled at 0 °C. HATU coupling reagent (22 mg, 0.059 mmol, 1.0 equiv) was added and stirred for 2 hours at 0 °C. Subsequently, NH2-TEMPO (25 mg, 0.146 mmol, 2.5 equiv) and 150 μL DIPEA were introduced. Stirred for 48 hours at room temperature. 0.5 mL of EtOH was added. Purified via silica gel column chromatography with CHCl3-EtOH (97-3) followed by precipitation in DCM/Pentane.

The title compound was isolated as a purple solid (18 mg, 30%). 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6 + 5% hydrazine): δ = 8.74 (d, J = 4.6 Hz, 2H), 8.69 (d, J = 4.6 Hz, 2H), 8.55 (m, 5H), 8.25 (m, 6H), 8.12 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 7.30 (s, 4H), 4.38 (m, 1H), 2.56 (s, 6H), 1.88 (m, 2H), 1.77 (s, 12H), 1.65 (m, 2H), 1.19 (s, 6H), 1.15 (s, 6H) ppm. MALDI-TOF: calcd for C61H58N6O4Zn [M+H]+ 1002.3811, found 1002.3863.

Synthesis of Hydroxa-ZnP-TEMPO (hyd-ZnP-TEMPO): HOOC-ZnP-TEMPO (20 mg, 0.020 mmol, 1.0 equiv) was dissolved in 5 mL dry DMF and HATU coupling reagent (15.2 mg, 0.040 mmol, 2.0 equiv) along with 15 μL DIPEA (0.08 mmol, 4 equiv) were added. Stirred at room temperature for 30 minutes. 10 equivalents of HCl·NH2OH (13.9 mg, 0.2 mmol) were introduced. Stirred for additional 6 hours at room temperature. 25 mL of water were added, precipitated, filtrated and washed with water.

Synthesis of hyd-ZnP: MeOOC-ZnP-COOH (17.3 mg, 0.020 mmol, 1.0 equiv) was dissolved in 5 mL dry DMF and HATU (15.4 mg, 0.040 mmol, 2.0 equiv) along with 15 μL DIPEA (0.081 mmol, 4 equiv) were added. Stirred at room temperature for 30 minutes, then 10 equivalents of HCl·NH2OH (14.1 mg, 0.202 mmol) were added and stirred overnight at room temperature. Precipitated with water, filtered and washed.
Isolated as a purple solid (15.2 mg, 85%). MALDI-TOF: calcd for C53H44N5O4Zn [M+H]+ 878.2685, found 878.2724. UV–Vis in THF [λmax/nm (ε/mM-1 cm-1)]: 426 (445.3), 556 (16.6), 598 (4.9).

Fabrication of TiO2 electrodes: F-doped SnO2 substrates fired at 450°C. Three steps: 1. Immersion in aqueous TiCl4 (0.3 mL pure TiCl4 in 500 mL water) at 80°C. 2. Screen printing with transparent colloidal paste 18NR-T (Dyesol) with drying steps at 150°C. 3. Final screen printed light scattering overlayer (18NR AO). Sintered at 450°C (ramp heating). Dyeing: Soaked while hot (80°C) in 0.2 mM dye solution in Toluene/EtOH (1/1) for 3 hours (optimized), then rinsed with dichloromethane.
Absorption and emission properties were recorded in Tetrahydrofuran (THF).

HO2C-ZnP-TEMPO: λabs = 426 (432.8), 557 (16.8), 598 (4.8) nm; λem = 607, 655 nm; E00 = 2.06 eV. hyd-ZnP-TEMPO: λabs = 426 (417.8), 557 (15.5), 597 (4.7) nm; λem = 606, 655 nm; E00 = 2.06 eV. The spectra display classical bands of tetraaryl zinc porphyrin with Soret transition at 426 nm and two Q transitions peaking at 555 and 598 nm.

The appended TEMPO moiety does not alter the absorption spectra of the ZnP-TEMPO dyads since there is no electronic communication between ZnP and TEMPO owing to the absence of a π-conjugated pathway. TEMPO does not quench the porphyrin singlet excited state by electron transfer.
Cyclic voltammetry on meso-ITO electrodes in acetonitrile containing 0.1 M LiClO4. Scan rate 50 mV/s.

HO2C-ZnP-TEMPO: EOx(TEMPO) = 0.73 V vs SCE, EOx(ZnP) = 0.79 V vs SCE. hyd-ZnP-TEMPO: EOx(TEMPO) = 0.74 V vs SCE, EOx(ZnP) = 0.84 V vs SCE. Oxidation potentials calculated as ΔGhs = EOx(TEMPO) - EOx(ZnP).

The two oxidation processes are quite close and not well separated. Zinc porphyrin oxidation occurs at about 100 mV higher potential than TEMPO, leaving a modest driving force for the hole shift reaction (+ZnP−TEMPO → ZnP−TEMPO+).
Light irradiation enables a significant potential gain of ca. 1 V for alcohol oxidation compared to thermodynamic potential.
DFT calculations using Gaussian 16.A.03, PBE0 functional and 6-311G(d,p) basis set. Solvent effects (ACN) with PCM model. Δ(self-consistent field) approach for adiabatic ionization potentials.

Unpaired electron is confined to TEMPO. Computed difference in MO energy between TEMPO and ZnP is -0.21 eV. Computed IPs: 5.08 eV for ZnP and 5.21 eV for TEMPO, leading to a driving force of -0.13 eV.
The saturated bridge prevents delocalization between the two moieties. The MO diagrams reveal that the unpaired electron of TEMPO appears slightly below the HOMO of ZnP.
fs-ps Electronic Transient Absorption (TA): 550 nm excitation of hyd-ZnP-TEMPO on TiO2 in borate electrolyte. Probing with white light (CaF2 plate). Pulse 30 fs at 5 kHz.
Immediate ESA band at 460 nm (S1 state of ZnP). Rise of a new band at 405-410 nm (radical cation of ZnP). Rise time reproduced with 6.3 and 75 ps time constants.

The changes in TA spectra are consistent with the formation of the radical cation of the ZnP subunit upon charge injection into TiO2. The decay of S1 at 460 nm is accompanied by recovery of GSB in Soret region.
ns-μs TA: 532 nm excitation (Nd:YAG, 300 ps pulse). Monitoring cation dynamics.
GSB and ZnP cation bands decay concurrently on multiple timescales: 2 ns, 50 ns, and 10 μs. Residual spectrum persists >100 μs.

In the absence of a TEMPO cation signature, it is impossible to determine if decay is due to hole shift to TEMPO or charge recombination. Suppression of ZnTPP cation by TEMPO in bimolecular experiments confirms hole shift is operative.
Dye loading quantification via desorption in 0.1 M Bu4NOH (THF/MeOH = 95:5) and UV-Vis quantification of characteristic Q-bands.
hyd-ZnP-TEMPO: 84 ± 10 nmol/cm2. hyd-ZnP: 110 ± 12 nmol/cm2.
Photovoltaic metrics in DSSCs: Iodide/triiodide redox couple in acetonitrile. Soaking time 3h in Toluene/EtOH. AM1.5 sunlight simulator (100 mW/cm2).
hyd-ZnP-TEMPO: Jsc = 3.45 ± 0.2 mA/cm2, Voc = 632 ± 5 mV, PCE = 1.65 ± 0.05%. HO2C-ZnP-TEMPO: Jsc = 4.3 ± 0.4 mA/cm2, Voc = 645 ± 10 mV, PCE = 2.00 ± 0.2%.
ZnP-TEMPO dyads outperform parent ZnP (PCE ~0.7%). Higher performance is ascribed to a longer-lived charge-separated state resulting from hole shift to TEMPO, which decreases recombination rate.
Photocatalytic para-methoxy benzyl alcohol (50 mM) oxidation in borate buffer (pH 7.5 - 10). Three-electrode PEC. 100 mW/cm2 illumination (400 nm cutoff).
Optimal pH = 8 for hyd-ZnP-TEMPO: Photocurrent (J) = 0.20 ± 0.05 mA/cm2, TON = 26 ± 4, TOF = 47 ± 7 h-1, FE = 82 ± 6%. At pH 10, FE = 93 ± 10%, but J drops to 0.09 mA/cm2.

Maximum rate and efficiency at pH 8. Efficiency decreases at higher pH likely due to faster desorption or degradation of TEMPO in basic conditions. Cathodic spikes without alcohol confirm recombination of injected electrons with oxidized TEMPO.
Photocatalytic oxidation in acetonitrile + 0.1 M N-methyl-imidazole (Me-Imd) for hyd-ZnP-TEMPO.

Lower performance compared to borate buffer due to faster desorption in acetonitrile. Me-Imd gives higher photocurrent than lutidine due to higher basicity and axial binding to ZnP limiting aggregation.
Comparison of hyd-ZnP-TEMPO (dyad) vs. bi-component system (hyd-ZnP + 1 mM ac-TEMPO) in acetonitrile.
Bi-component system: J = 0.12 ± 0.04 mA/cm2, TON = 10 ± 2, TOF = 18 ± 3 h-1, FE = 85 ± 6%.
Performances are alike, but TOF is higher with the dyad due to proximity-driven faster hole shift. Dyad allows easier catalyst recovery by rinsing.
Comparison of anchoring group stability (Carboxylic vs. Hydroxamic acid) during long-term irradiation.
Photocurrent of carboxylic acid dyad (HO2C-ZnP-TEMPO) decays more abruptly than hydroxamic dyad (hyd-ZnP-TEMPO). In acetonitrile, HO2C-ZnP-TEMPO desorbs too fast to allow product quantification.
Hydroxamic acid anchor provides a more robust binding to TiO2, crucial in organic electrolytes where the dyad is soluble.
Substrate scope for benzyl alcohol oxidation using hyd-ZnP-TEMPO (MeO-Ph-CH2OH, Ph-CH2OH, and CF3-Ph-CH2OH) in borate buffer pH 8.
MeO-Ph-CH2OH: 0.20 mA/cm2. Ph-CH2OH: 0.19 mA/cm2. CF3-Ph-CH2OH: 0.50 mA/cm2.
CF3-Ph-CH2OH produces much higher photocurrent, likely due to higher hydrophobicity improving affinity to the lipophilic environments of the porphyrin/TEMPO coated photoanode.
Faradaic Efficiency (FE) measurement using gas chromatography.
Selectivity toward para-methoxy benzaldehyde was 100% (no over-oxidation observed).
The TEMPO-based DSPEC system selectively oxidizes alcohols to aldehydes with high Faradaic efficiency (>80%).
